recipe.name: Mexican Lasagna Enchilada Stack
recipe.description: An enchilada - layered like a lasagna! Made with Pork Carnitas (Mexican Pulled Pork) but you can substitute with any shredded or diced (cooked) chicken, beef or pork. This recipe makes 4 generous servings or 6 small servings.
recipeIngredient: 2 cups shredded Pork Carnitas ((Mexican Pulled Pork) (see notes))
1 can (400g/15oz)   black beans ( or red kidney beans)
2 1/4 cups enchilada sauce (, separated (preferably homemade - here's my Easy Classic Enchilada Sauce))
1 cup grated mozzarella cheese ((or any other melting cheese))
Fresh parsley or coriander (, finely chopped (optional - for garnish))

recipeInstructions.text: Combine the Pork Carnitas, corn, black beans, capsicum and 1 1/2 cups of enchilada sauce in a bowl. Mix to combine.
recipeInstructions.name: Combine the Pork Carnitas, corn, black beans, capsicum and 1 1/2 cups of enchilada sauce in a bowl. Mix to combine.

recipeInstructions.text: Spread 1 tbsp of enchilada sauce on the base of a baking dish.
recipeInstructions.name: Spread 1 tbsp of enchilada sauce on the base of a baking dish.

recipeInstructions.text: Line the baking dish with tortillas. I find the best way to do this is to cut the tortillas in half, place 2 on the baking dish (with the straight cut side lined to the edge of the baking dish), then cut 1 tortilla into 6 to 8 pieces and use those wedges to fill the gaps.
recipeInstructions.name: Line the baking dish with tortillas. I find the best way to do this is to cut the tortillas in half, place 2 on the baking dish (with the straight cut side lined to the edge of the baking dish), then cut 1 tortilla into 6 to 8 pieces and use those wedges to fill the gaps.

recipeInstructions.text: Spread half the filling across the tortillas.
recipeInstructions.name: Spread half the filling across the tortillas.

recipeInstructions.text: Top with another layer of tortillas, then spread the remaining filling on top.
recipeInstructions.name: Top with another layer of tortillas, then spread the remaining filling on top.

recipeInstructions.text: Top with a third and final layer of tortillas. Spread remaining enchilada sauce (3/4 cup) across the top, then sprinkle with mozzarella cheese.
recipeInstructions.name: Top with a third and final layer of tortillas. Spread remaining enchilada sauce (3/4 cup) across the top, then sprinkle with mozzarella cheese.

recipeInstructions.text: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes until the cheese is melted and started to turn golden.
recipeInstructions.name: Bake for 20 to 25 minutes until the cheese is melted and started to turn golden.

recipeInstructions.text: Let stand for 5 minutes, then garnish with parsley or coriander if desired and serve.
recipeInstructions.name: Let stand for 5 minutes, then garnish with parsley or coriander if desired and serve.

review.reviewBody: I had a rotisserie chicken that I needed to use, so I decided to give this recipe a try. I was short on time so I used jarred sauce, subbed cheddar cheese, and pinto beans. It turned out delicious! Something to note, I used a 9x13 glass casserole dish. It took a lot longer to cook. Closer to 45 mins. I suspect it was due to the glass dish and I used more than 2 cups of chicken. Another great recipe, Nagi!

This worked really well. I used leftover pulled pork and made the suggested enchilada sauce as it was much cheaper than buying a jar of ready made sauce. I also used 8 tortillas and just cut them in half and placed the flat side on the four edges of a small square baking dish which meant I got 4 layers. I had never made a tortilla bake before but seeing how incredibly easy they are and how well they turn out, I will be making this and other similar recipes from now on. Thanks for posting Nagi, you rock!

Hi nagi,
Hoping to give this a go. I have greek pita bread and mission wholegrain wraps staring at me from the fridge? would they be any good or do I have to get a tortilla ? Whatever makes this taste good, I will go for it.
I really like Mexican Lasagna Enchilada Stack. It feels very good. I tried it at home and it was great. thanks.

I guess what they say is true what's old is new. My mom who is as white as they come, but had the good fortune  to marry a great Mexican from Yuma, Arizona made this recipe for us when we were young. No black beans she used pinto instead. In fact I sent this to my sister and she couldn't believe it! Now this may not sound so unusual but I'm 62 and she's 58! Thanks for memories long forgotten.
